thread.title: Australia’s secret dining hotspots

author: The Telegraph
title: Australia’s secret dining hotspots
text: Youthful, free-spirited Australian cuisine is worth going halfway around the world for. In fact there are foodies who say the “golden egg” dessert at Sydney’s Sepia restaurant justifies the journey on its own. But what if the queue is too long at that gourmet dining room, your budget is tight or you want to eat like a local? As ever in a country famed for its informality, insider knowledge could save you a buck and impress friends. Momofuku Seiobo is chef David Chang’s stellar Sydney restaurant, regularly ranked among the country’s top 10. Tables are booked far in advance, but for a taster you can enjoy snacks such as his signature spanner crab roll at the five-seater bar. Alternatively, visit the fish market to buy ocean-fresh ingredients and cook lunch on the beach. Ask for a dozen just-shucked Sydney rocks at Christie’s oyster counter and you’ll beat the crowds out front. Still in the NSW capital, the Friday Chinatown night market is a buzzing place to enjoy authentic street food on the cheap. Or venture into the suburb of Stanmore to dine at Sixpenny. Here some of Australia’s most inventive young chefs guest in the kitchen on the second Sunday of each month. If business (or pleasure) takes you to Canberra, investigate open days at the various foreign embassies. These take place throughout the year and allow you to feast on Chinese, Russian or Indonesian cuisine, for example, often in opulent surroundings. There’s also a great farmers’ market at Epic Park, where culinary attractions include home-grown black truffles. Fine fare: vegetarian restaurant Urbane is a delight for the senses Further north, Brisbane is a melting pot of world cuisine, with authentic ramen to enjoy at Taro’s, tapas and paella at Moda, hip Middle-Eastern specialities chez Gerard’s and a revelatory vegetarian set menu at Urbane – all of them affordably priced. In Western Australia, take a guided bush walk to forage for native foods, and taste kangaroo, emu, quandong and saltbush around the campfire. The freshest locally-sourced ingredients are de rigueur at Rockpool and Co-op Dining, and both these elite Perth addresses have walk-up bars should the full degustation feel like too much of a good thing. Foraging feast: take a guided bush walk to try Australia's native foods Enjoy a hearty breakfast while grazing Adelaide’s Central Market, then head over to Thebarton for a flight of whiskies at the Wheatsheaf Hotel – three drams (your choice or theirs) for 21 dollars. Not a fan of spirits? One of South Australia’s most impressive wine lists is to be admired at fermentAsian, a gourmet Vietnamese restaurant in the heart of the Barossa Valley. Neither is there any shortage of liquid refreshments in the state of Victoria. Craft beers are the draw at East of Everything in Camberwell, while in the garden at the Moon Under Water in Fitzroy you can take your pick from a magnificent cellar, even if you’re not dining. Keep Tuesday free to eat at internationally-renowned Attica, when the kitchen tries out new dishes at reduced rates. Simply chic: Moon Under Water in Fitzroy, Victoria is a must for foodie fans Tasmanian mutton bird is love or loathe, but if you want to give it a go head for Constitution Dock in Hobart. While you’re on the island, keep an eye open for Big Bessie – a vintage green and white truck selling mind-blowing ice cream. Finally, check out the Museum of Old and New Art, which has affordable bars and a year-round programme of food and wine events to inspire your next trip.
